name: STP
description: Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) prevents Layer 2 loops in switched networks by blocking redundant paths. Modern variants include RSTP (Rapid STP) and PVST+ (Per-VLAN STP).
key_topics: Port states: Blocking, Listening, Learning, Forwarding, Disabled
Port roles: Root port, Designated port, Alternate port, Backup port
Path cost calculation based on link speed
PVST+ (Per-VLAN Spanning Tree Plus) - Cisco proprietary
PortFast and BPDU Guard for edge ports
common_misconceptions: Many training resources state that STP port states are always sequential. Cisco documentation shows RSTP's alternate and backup ports can transition directly to forwarding, skipping listening and learning
Third-party materials often confuse root port selection. Cisco's tie-breakers are: 1) lowest path cost, 2) lowest sender Bridge ID, 3) lowest sender port ID, 4) lowest receiver port ID
Training books frequently claim PortFast is only for end-user devices. Cisco guides clarify PortFast should NEVER be enabled on ports connected to switches or bridges as it bypasses loop prevention
Common error: assuming all VLANs share one spanning tree. Cisco's PVST+ runs a separate STP instance per VLAN, unlike standard 802.1D
